readabilityHelper.formula.description: The formula to use for calculating readability score
enumDescriptions: The Automated Readability Index returns a score roughly matching the U.S. grade level it takes to understand a text.
The Coleman-Liau index returns a score roughly matching the U.S. grade level it takes to understand a text.

The Dale-Chall readability formula returns a score between around 1 and 10, where 5 or lower is easily understood by a 4th-grade student, 7 is easily understood by a 9th grader, and 10 is easily understood by a college student.
The Flesch Reading-Ease test returns a score between 100 and 0, where 100 is very easy to read and 0 is best understood by university graduates.
The Flesch-Kincaid grade level test returns a score roughly matching the U.S. grade level (or number of years of education) it takes to understand a text.
The SMOG grade estimates the years of education needed to understand a text.
The Spache readability formula returns a grade level score. It works best on texts for children up to fourth grade.

readabilityHelper.warningsEnabled.description: Controls whether a warning is displayed when the document's readability score is harder than the defined score

readabilityHelper.warnScore.automated-re.description: Approximate U.S. grade level: 1 = Kindergarten, 5 = Fifth grade, 13 = College student

readabilityHelper.warnScore.dale-chall.description: 0-10, where 5 or lower is easily understood by young students and 10 is for college students

readabilityHelper.warnScore.flesch.description: 0-100, where 0 is extremely difficult to read and 100 is very easy to read

readabilityHelper.warnScore.spache.description: Approximate U.S. grade level. Works best on text for children up to fourth grade (for older children, the Dale-Chall formula is more appropriate)
